result.execSummary:
The defendant Scott A Oleson was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Resisting or Obstructing an Officer, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.41(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.descr: DE not competent to stand trial, case suspended

records.addlTxt: FAX confirmation
of Commitment for Treatment (Incompetency)

2:23 Defendant Scott A Oleson in court with attorney Emily M Nolan-Plutchak.  Defendant Scott A Oleson in custody.  Michael Daniel Zell appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Attorney Zell states he has reviewed the competency report and has no comment.
Attorney Nolan Plutchak states that she has reviewed the report as well and has no comment.
Court questions defendant and he states he is competent to proceed. 
Dr. Michael Galli appears by phone and is sworn as a witness and questioned by Attorney Zell. He states that defendant is not competent because of mental illness, but with proper treatment may become competent. He recommends that defendant be given medication to treat his mental illness. Attorney Nolan-Plutchak cross-examines witness. Court questions witness. Court accepts Dr. Galli's report.
Court finds defendant is incompetent to proceed because of mental illness. With proper treatment, defendant is likely to become competent and Court orders the involuntary administration of psychotropic medications. Court suspends proceedings and defendant is committed to the custody of the Dept of Health Services for a period of 9 months. Defendant currently has 24 days credit. Sheriff's Department will transport defendant to and from designated facility. Facility should provide Court with status report at 3, 6 and 9 months.
Attorney Nolan Plutchak states defendant wishes to have a signature bond and family will transport him. She asks that court order that he be transported forthwith so he is not being held in jail for an extended period of time. Court denies signature bond request. Court denies request to sign an order stating forthwith and states reasons for that.
FAX cover from Dr. Galli with competency report
Sealed by the Court
FAX cover and confirmation
